newsitem.title: FRANCE: French gross farm income seen steady in 1996-INSEE.
newsitem.headline: French gross farm income seen steady in 1996-INSEE.

text.p: French gross farm income is expected to remain steady in 1996 after jumping 10.4 percent in 1995 and 11.5 percent in 1995, national statistics institute INSEE said on Tuesday.
Provisional accounts for agriculture in 1996 showed the beef, milk and wine sectors were hit by lower sales volume and prices, while grain producers just maintained revenue.
In a statement INSEE said deliveries of farm products rose 1.5 percent in volume but were down 1.2 percent in value.
Grain deliveries jumped by 13 percent on record yields and increased area to reach their highest level in 10 years.
But bumper crops in France and elsewhere in the European Union and prospects of higher end-season stocks may drive grain prices down by five percent in 1996, INSEE said.
Cattle prices slumped a provisional 12 percent in 1996 after a consumer scare over so-called mad cow disease.
Despite lower beef consumption, cattle deliveries rose 1.5 percent in volume due to buying by intervention stores, higher exports and lower imports.
Overall compensation payments to the farm sector rose by 2.7 billion francs in 1996.
But this included 1.6 billion francs in aid paid to the beef sector.
